I support the amendment, I think it is a reasonable amendment and should be accepted. Strangely enough, the Commission for Energy Regulation was very involved at the start of this legislation and all of a sudden it disappeared.

The Government said it was a matter for the Commission for Energy Regulation to set the costs and charges and said it had nothing to do with the Minister or the Department of the Environment, Community and Local Government. Has the commission come back on the scene or is it gone?

I am surprised representatives of Irish Water are not in the House tonight. We are here. They are the people getting €100,000 and €150,000 as well as bonuses. They are all at home with their families. Perhaps they are watching it on television tonight and having a good laugh, because that is what is happening.
In fairness, they are watching "The Graham Norton Show".

I like the introduction for the Abbey Theatre. I cannot understand where the Department of Social Protection comes into it. Can the Minister explain it? Where does the Department of Social Protection come into a situation to do with the taking of business-----
How is that relevant to this amendment?
Okay. I will come back.
The amendment is specific enough.
It is relevant to the water conservation package.
I will deal with the matter on the section.

The water conservation grant is another sliding mirror smokescreen. Senator Healy Eames is correct to suggest this is all about getting people to sign up and nothing else. I cannot understand how the Minister will gather whether we have conserved anything. Are we going to employ inspectors to check what conservation measures have taken place in each house? Do I simply sign up and state that I have conserved water or carried out water conservation in my house? One explanation is that it will contribute towards bringing the network up to standard to meet metric tests established by the Commission for Energy Regulation. We are moving around between different Departments. It is a question of sliding mirrors and smokescreens. It is just another scam to get people to sign up, nothing else. We induce people with €100. We get them in for €260 for a couple of years but then we will have to double, triple or quadruple the costs to pay back the money that the Government will have borrowed in the meantime.

All of this is assuming the company lasts past its first year. I believe it will be insolvent within a few months because no one is going to pay. This is my problem - no one is going to pay. Where do we go then? We have a vast quango with thousands of employees and no way of paying them or no way for the company to pay for itself. The Minister should not try to cod us. People are watching this tonight and wondering what we are playing at.
All of the playing is over on the other side.

I appeal to the Minister to indicate that the Government will consider taking at least one amendment. If not, then those in charge should let us all go home to bed. Then, we will come back on Monday and have a discussion on Report Stage during which the Minister will probably take no amendments either. Let us stop the game-playing. Let us go home - we are all tired - if the Minister is not going to take an amendment.

Senator Healy Eames has been very proactive on this legislation. She has put a good deal of work into her amendments and they are thoughtful. From my perspective they are rather helpful, in particular, the amendment currently tabled because most of the debate on Second Stage and throughout today was on the question of conservation. Since all the meters are not in place there is no way of saying what we are achieving in the area of conservation at the moment. However, it was supposed to be one of the main selling points of Uisce Éireann from day 1.

I cannot see how this amendment is not seen as being helpful, not only to Members making contributions but to the Minister and the Government as well. At this stage there may not be any idea as to how it would be done. However, this amendment would focus and challenge us over the coming months to come up with some methodology to tie down this issue once and for all.

I am not keen for us to encounter a sudden realisation when this legislation is being implemented that conservation has gone out the window and is no longer part of the agenda. I know the Minister does not want to see that, the Government does not want that and no reasonable person wants to see it either. All the contributions I have heard from all the positions on this legislation put conservation high on the priority list. This amendment would help us to focus on doing that. Even at this late hour, I call on the Minister to consider whether he sees any merit in the amendment.

I raised some points on this issue on Second Stage and the Minister may be familiar with my views. It is clear there is a potential flaw, not so much in the legislation but because of the disincentive to conserve. We are full of contradictions in this House. First, we do not want to cap usage or the charge on usage. However, this section gets to the heart of the philosophy behind the Bill, which is about conserving water. Certainly, for the first period or up to 2018 there is no incentive to conserve water and yet we are all going to get €100 for doing so.

In one way the other side of the House need not worry about it because it means we will all pay less. It will reduce the amount for water on a weekly basis in the first place and it will be utterly uncapped. In other words, there is no incentive to conserve water. We could keep the taps running between now and December 2018 and that is a concern.
The other issue I want to raise on this section-----
We are discussing the amendment. I will let you in on the section later.

The other issue relates to rain harvesting. How does that fit in? I seek a general policy statement from the Minister on where he sees rain harvesting contributing to conservation. In particular, where does he see it in this Bill? If he does not see it within the Bill then where might he see it as part of future legislation? The concern I have, which I also raised on Second Stage, relates to the possible punishment of customers and if rain-harvesting is used particularly in replacement of wastewater.

There are many problems with this conservation measure. First, it is not related to conservation. The memorandum states that people get €100 per household which people "can use to assist with water conservation in their homes". They could use it to buy watering cans, garden sprinklers or to buy €100 worth of Ballygowan water. I am unsure what it is supposed to be conserving. It is all over the place.

Second, it is unrelated to income. We are paying this out to millionaires for their swimming pools and so on. Subsidies of this kind have no place in an economy that is still borrowing €8 billion per year. It gives the same to people on social welfare as sur-taxpayers. It is an unconstrained transfer and has nothing to do with conservation.

It is paid from the Department of Social Protection. I have argued in the House many times that the universalism of benefits like child benefit paid in this unconstrained way right up the income scale of sur-taxpayers, millionaires and so on is wrong. The redistribution of social welfare in particular should be towards low-income people. We should pay more attention to the couple who must pay the €260 poll tax that Irish Water has imposed.

The Commission for Energy Regulation is supposed to be advising on the matter. It put up the public service obligation by over 50% for electricity. The commission has already given us the highest prices for electricity found anywhere in Europe. The belief of some Ministers in quangos for the purposes of serving consumer interests is extraordinary.

The Central Bank could not regulate banks. Bus fares have increased massively and they are supposed to be regulated by the National Transport Authority. Health insurance costs increased by 58% when we have the Health Insurance Authority. It suits civil servants to say there is a quango to deal with something but they appoint the quango which does what it is told and never represents the consumer. The idea that the Commission for Energy Regulation should have any role in this is unacceptable. It has done enough damage already to consumers of water and energy in this country.

I am beginning to feel that the more we go through this legislation we find more holes than there would be in a leaky Irish Water mains pipe, but we will continue to raise the issues we are raising. I am dumbfounded by what I am hearing from the Ministers on the questions we are raising. This is a bona fide amendment into which there has been a good deal of thought. I am confused as to the reason the Department of Social Protection has been chosen to make the payment on the conservation grant scheme. From what we have heard it is clear it is not really measurable as a conservation measure. We are told that the Department of Social Protection is so strapped we had to see cuts in fuel allowances, respite care, child benefit, mobility grants, etc., but all of a sudden the Government can turn around and offer every household in the country this €100 grant. I wonder about the implications of the cost of that. What is the actual cost? How many households are involved? What is the estimated total cost of the conservation grant? The amendment is about publishing a report outlining how it is being implemented-----
Senator, we will be dealing with that under your amendment No. 21.
Surely when a new scheme is being implemented there are projected costs. That is what this is about. It is about reporting back.
We will be dealing with amendment No. 21 separately. That is what you wanted.

The point I am making is that before we can review a scheme we have to have projections. I am asking the Minister very clear questions. What are the projections? How many households do they intend to pay the grant to? How much of a hole will that leave in the social protection budget, and has that been signed off on by Cabinet and by the Minister for Social Protection?

In terms of the principle of this, it is like borrowing money from a loan shark. It seems like a good idea at the time but in the longer run we will end up paying much more and being a lot more indebted. This is the carrot being used again. It is just another Irish Water scam by this Government and it no longer has any credibility in my view. The Minister should give us detail on this because we got very little detail on most of the questions we have asked so far in this debate, and it appears there has been very little thought put into most of the measures in the Bill. It strikes me that Irish Water 1, 2 and 3 are episodes of another debacle.

There is an entire lack of honesty about this so-called grant. It is so dishonest it is outrageous. It would be far better if the Government and the Minister put their hands up and said that they were hoping to charge people more. The Commission for Energy Regulation, as we know, published our water charges plan. The average cost was to be €400. People came out and marched on the streets and rebelled against the tax and the charge. The Government had to do something about it. It floundered around trying to come up with some way to reduce the charge, and it came up with the water conservation grant. That is what it is; it is not a conservation grant. It was the Government's way to reduce the charge. We should at least be honest about that. There is no honesty here at all.

I would imagine the Minister will not be able to point to a single scrap of evidence as to how this conservation grant will lead to water being conserved. Why in God's name would the Department of Social Protection provide people with a grant to conserve water? Surely that is a matter for the Department of the Environment, Community and Local Government. It is not a conservation grant. There is no relationship between water conservation and this so-called grant which is being paid. People will get that and they can do with it what they choose. The reason they are getting it is so that they can do with it what they choose because it is purely designed to reduce the cost of the charge to the user. If we had a bit of honesty about this-----
The Senator does not want to-----
With respect Senator, I do not want people to pay at all. I am saying this is entirely dishonest.
It is entirely dishonest.
It is called a water services grant-----
Exactly.
-----but this amendment is looking for some proof. There is a metric test carried out by the Commission for Energy Regulation to-----
Is the Senator opposed to the grant?
The Senator without interruption.
I am opposed to the Arthur Daly school of economics-----
Hear, hear.
Senator, on the amendment please.

-----that we are getting from this Government in regard to this issue. It is rubbish. Here we are at 12.15 a.m. on Saturday morning and almost the exact same thing happened to us in the Water Services Bill mark 1 where all of this nonsense happened.
Senator, on amendment No. 19 please.

We are not getting answers to questions. We are all frustrated. I will wait to see if the Minister answers this one because the Minister of State, Deputy Coffey, has not answered most of the questions we have asked.
He did.
He waffled on. Can the Minister be honest and tell us that this is not about water conservation-----
Senator Daly.
-----that the Government got it wrong and it is giving us €100 off the bill to reduce the cost? The Minister should be honest with us.
On a point of order, when the question was asked whether we agreed to debate amendments Nos. 19 to 21, inclusive, I replied that we were not taking them together.
We are on amendment No. 19.
The screen indicates amendments Nos. 19 to 21, inclusive.
Yes, they were meant to be taken together.
That is only a caption. What happens in the House is different, Senator. We are on amendment No. 19.
I just wanted to clarify that.

On the clarity being sought on the issue, is this really a mechanism to give people money and to allow the Government to get around European regulations? Is that the purpose behind this? The dread of any legislator is where legislation states that the Minister may make regulations for the purpose of this section to provide for the following: the amount of the grant, the eligibility criteria, the application procedure, the information to be provided by the persons - I assume PPS numbers will not be part of that - general administration procedures and any conciliatory or auxiliary measures the Minister considers necessary. Basically, the Bill states that the Minister can write the law and make up any regulations he requires, and this section gives him the absolute power-----
We are on amendment No. 19 Senator.
But that is section 5-----
Senator, we will deal with the section separately. We are on amendment No. 19.

We are asking that within six months the Minister will prepare a report, and this goes back to my earlier point to which I did not receive a reply. I was not allowed ask the Minister the follow-up question. I asked twice whether any regulatory impact assessment was done. This is a report we would like to see laid before the Houses. The central topic is whether anybody in the Department of the Environment, Community and Local Government bothered to look at the consequences of its new policy that water would not be turned off? That is a report-----
Senator, you are not debating the amendment.
